Itâ€™s Monday. We try to keep things as light as we can in this newsletter, and weâ€™ll get back to doing that soon, but the events of this weekend were a dark moment for the countryâ€”and we take that seriously.

Quick Hits: Todayâ€™s Top Stories

President Joe Biden addressed the nation from the Oval Office on Sunday evening, urging Americans to â€œlower the temperatureâ€ of political rhetoric after the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump on Saturday. The FBIâ€”working with the Secret Serviceâ€”is leading the investigation into the shooting at a campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, on Saturday, that left one dead and three injured, including the former president. The FBI has also identified a suspect in the shooting: a 20-year-old Pennsylvania native who worked as a dietary aid at a nursing and rehabilitation center. Secret Service snipers shot him just moments after he opened fire on the rally, and law enforcement later reportedly found explosives in his car parked near the event. Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro said Sunday that Corey Comperatore, a 50-year-old retired fire chief, died of a gunshot wound in Saturdayâ€™s shooting after he threw himself between his family and the gunfire. Two other people who were shot and wounded remain in â€œcritical conditionâ€ and were being treated Sunday at a Pittsburgh hospital. Trump said the attempt on his life would not alter his travel plans to this weekâ€™s Republican National Convention in Milwaukee. â€œBased on yesterdayâ€™s terrible events, I was going to delay my trip to Wisconsin, and The Republican National Convention, by two days,â€ Trump posted on Truth Social on Sunday. â€œBut have just decided that I cannot allow a â€˜shooter,â€™ or potential assassin, to force change to scheduling, or anything else.â€

Prior to the attempt on Trumpâ€™s life on Saturday, President Biden spoke with Democratic members of Congress in an attempt to reassure them that he can still beat the presumptive Republican nominee in November after more than a dozen said they believed he should withdraw from the race. Lawmakers on that call reportedly said it was â€œtenseâ€ and a â€œdisaster,â€ but even so, the push to force Biden out seemedâ€”publicly, at leastâ€”to have lost momentum on Sunday in the wake of the assassination attempt against the former president.

The Israel Defense Forces (IDF) on Saturday launched an airstrike targeting Muhammad Deif, the leader of the military branch of Hamas, and Rafah Salameh, the leader of Hamasâ€™ military operations in the southern city of Khan Younis. The strike occurred in a section of Gaza designated as a humanitarian zone, but one out of which Israeli officials have accused Hamas of operating and launching rockets. The Hamas-run Gaza Health Ministry claimed that 90 people were killed; Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu confirmed Saturday that the IDF had targeted Deif and Salameh but did not yet have â€œabsolute clarityâ€ regarding whether he had been killed. Deifâ€”who was an architect of the October 7 attacks and has reportedly been instrumental in bringing new weapons and military technology to Hamasâ€™ Qassam Brigadesâ€”has not been seen publicly in many years, and survived a similar attack in 2014.

A New York judge dismissed bankruptcy proceedings on Friday for former New York City mayor and longtime Trump ally Rudy Giuliani after he failed to turn over necessary financial records. The dismissal could allow the two Georgia election poll workers whom Giuliani was convicted of defaming last year to begin collecting their $146 million in damages awarded by a federal jury in December. â€œMr. Giuliani would often promise to file monthly operating reports by a certain date, only to miss those deadlines,â€ New York bankruptcy Judge Sean Lane wrote. â€œPerhaps even more troubling, the information in the monthly operating reports has been incomplete or inaccurate. â€¦ This lack of transparencyâ€”apparently even to Mr. Giulianiâ€™s own counselâ€”raises significant concerns about Mr. Giulianiâ€™s ability and willingness to manage the bankruptcy estate in the best interest of his creditors.â€

AT&T revealed Friday that a massive data breach between May and October 2022 had exposed the phone numbers of â€œnearly allâ€ AT&T customers. Hackers were also able to access a record of every call or text made by an AT&T customerâ€”even to those who use other networksâ€”as well as the duration of each of these calls, though not the content of those calls or texts. The data was illegally downloaded through the companyâ€™s workspace on Snowflakeâ€”a third-party cloud platform. AT&T claimed that at least one of the hackers associated with the hack was in custody.

Barbora Krejcikova won the Wimbledon womenâ€™s singles over the weekend, beating out Italyâ€™s Jasmine Paolini to win her second major singles tournament. The 28-year-old player from the Czech Republic has had prior success in doubles matchesâ€”including a doubles gold medal at the 2020 Tokyo Olympicsâ€”and entered Wimbledon this year as the 31st seed. Meanwhile, Carlos Alcaraz defeated Novak Djokovic in straight sets on Sunday in the final of the Wimbledon menâ€™s singles. The No. 3 seed Alcaraz prevailed over No. 2 seed Djokovicâ€”who was hampered by a knee injuryâ€”to claim his second Wimbledon title and become just the sixth menâ€™s player to win Wimbledon and the French Open in the same year.

Spain defeated England 2-1 on Sunday to win the Euro 2024 tournamentâ€”Spainâ€™s fourth European championship, more than any other nation. Also on Sunday, Argentina defeated Colombia 1-0 in extra time in the Copa America. The latter match, held in Miami, was delayed 82 minutes due to difficulties getting fans into Hard Rock Stadium.

Fitness personality Richard Simmonsâ€”known for his flamboyant home workout routinesâ€”passed away on Saturday at the age of 76. A spokesperson for the Los Angeles Fire Department said he died of natural causes.

â€˜Itâ€™s Time to Cool it Downâ€™

In a press conference on Sunday morning, Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro revealed the name of the man who died during the attempt on former President Donald Trumpâ€™s life on Saturday evening: Corey Comperatore, a 50-year-old father of two from Pennsylvania. â€œCorey was a girl-dad. Corey was a firefighter. Corey went to church every Sunday,â€ Shapiro said, after speaking to Comperatoreâ€™s widow and two daughters. â€œI asked Coreyâ€™s wife if it would be okay for me to share that we spoke. She said yes. She also asked that I share with all of you that Corey died a hero; that Corey dove on his family to protect them last night at this rally. Corey was the very best of us. May his memory be a blessing.â€ Two other victims were critically wounded in the shooting, but have yet to be identified as of Sunday evening.

More than 24 hours after the tragedy in Butler County, Pennsylvania, that left Comperatore dead, two others critically wounded, and Trump shot in the ear, new details are slowly emerging about how Saturdayâ€™s rally unfolded. President Joe Biden addressed the nation on Sunday night, encouraging Americans to â€œlower the temperature in our politics.â€ With the Republican National Convention set to kick off today, security will be tight as the gathered politicians, journalists, and delegates reflect on this weekendâ€™s events.

Speaking from the Oval Office, Biden condemned political violence and called on political leaders and the public alike to turn down the temperature. â€œWe cannot, we must not, go down this road in America,â€ he said. â€œWe cannot allow this violence to be normalized. You know the political rhetoric of this country has gotten very heated. Itâ€™s time to cool it down. We all have a responsibility to do that.â€

â€œWhile unity is the most elusive of all goals right now, nothing is more important for us now than standing together,â€ he added. Bidenâ€”who promised in his January inaugural address that his â€œwhole soulâ€ was in â€œbringing America together, uniting our people, and uniting our nationâ€â€”will return to the campaign trail tomorrow, speaking at the NAACP National Convention in Las Vegas on Tuesday.

Bidenâ€™s speech followed remarks he delivered earlier on Sunday afternoon after receiving a briefing from federal law enforcement officials about the assassination attempt against his political opponent. He implored the country to not make assumptions about the shooterâ€™s motives or political affiliation while investigations are ongoing. The president also said he had directed the head of the Secret Service to review all of the security measures for the RNC and ordered an â€œindependent review of the national security at yesterdayâ€™s rally to assess exactly what happened.â€

And almost every hour after the shooting on Saturday has resulted in new information emerging about what exactly did happen. On Sunday, there was a slow trickle of additional details about the suspected shooter, whom Secret Service snipers killed seconds after he opened fire on the former president and rallygoers at about 6:15 p.m. ET. The FBI confirmed the suspect in the assassination attempt was 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks of Bethel Park, Pennsylvania, saying as of Sunday that the suspect seems to have â€œacted alone and that there are currently no public safety concerns.â€

The FBI is treating the investigation both as an attempted assassination and as a potential instance of domestic terrorismâ€”which, according to the FBIâ€™s definition, is a violent act intended to shape U.S. government policy in some way. The suspectâ€™s gun was legally purchased by his father, according to law enforcement. Explosive devices were reportedly found in the suspectâ€™s carâ€”which was parked near the rallyâ€”and at his family home in Bethel Park, about an hour away.

But the suspected gunmanâ€™s motivations remain unclear. His political affiliationsâ€”to the extent that he actually had anyâ€”seem ambiguous, and authorities said Sunday his social media accounts hadnâ€™t provided clues as to what may have caused him to try to assassinate the former president. Former high school classmates described him as a loner who was quiet and not obviously interested in politics. He apparently tried out for his high schoolâ€™s rifle team, but was rejected. â€œAt present, we have not identified an ideology associated with the subject,â€ Kevin Rojek, the FBIâ€™s Pittsburgh Special Agent in Charge, said Sunday. â€œBut I want to remind everyone that weâ€™re still very early in this investigation.â€

There are also still a lot of unanswered questions about the security lapse that allowed the shooter to get within 200 yards of the former president with a rifle and open fire. The building atop which the shooter was perched had been designated as part of local police jurisdiction, a Secret Service spokesperson said, but law enforcement had not secured it. Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle and in both houses of Congress signaled Sunday they would investigate federal law enforcementâ€™s actions and protocols. â€œThe seriousness of this security failure and chilling moment in our nationâ€™s history cannot be understated,â€ GOP Rep. Mark Green, the chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee, wrote in a letter to Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Sec. Alejandro Mayorkas, whose department oversees the Secret Service. â€œAs the U.S. Secret Service (USSS) investigates, the Committee on Homeland Security (Committee) is dedicated to conducting rigorous oversight to ensure that the American people receive answers and presidential candidates receive proper and adequate protection.â€

Likewise, the chairs of the House Oversight and Intelligence Committees and the Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs are all investigating the federal law enforcementâ€™s handling of the rally and the shooting, Axios reported. GOP Rep. James Comer, chair of the House Oversight Committee, has called Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle to appear before lawmakers on July 22. GOP Rep. Mike Waltz alleged yesterday that the DHS had denied requests to beef up Trumpâ€™s security, though Anthony Guglielmi, a spokesman for the Secret Service, denied that claim. â€œTheres an untrue assertion that a member of the former Presidentâ€™s team requested additional security resources & that those were rebuffed,â€ he tweeted. â€œThis is absolutely false. In fact, we added protective resources & technology & capabilities as part of the increased campaign travel tempo.â€

Trump flew to Milwaukee yesterday, where security at the Republican National Convention is now front and center. But the Secret Service and local law enforcement say theyâ€™re prepared. â€œThere have been no changes to our current operational security plans for this event,â€ said Audrey Gibson-Cicchino, the Secret Serviceâ€™s coordinator for the convention, noting that the event is already receiving the highest level of security that the Secret Service provides. â€œWe are confident in the security plans that are in place for this event.â€ Milwaukee Police Chief Jeffrey Norman said yesterday, â€œI just wanted to reassure those not only in the convention but also in our city: We got this.â€

Beyond just the physical security, the weekendâ€™s events could also affect the tenor of the event. Even before Saturdayâ€™s assassination attempt, RNC officials seemed to be expanding the tent. On Wednesday, Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis was added to the speaking schedule after initial reports that he had been snubbed. A similar process played out with former Gov. Nikki Haley, who received an invitation to participate shortly before the shooting on Saturday evening. Yesterday, a Haley aide confirmed that she will be in Milwaukee this week and speak to the convention on Tuesday.

The Trump campaign itself has internally emphasized turning down the heat in the wake of the assassination attempt. Trump campaign managers Chris LaCivita and Susie Wiles shared a memo with staff following the shooting, urging them â€œto recognize the political polarization in this heated electionâ€ and warning that they â€œwill not tolerate dangerous rhetoric on social media.â€ A little over an hour after the shooting on Saturday, LaCivita tweeted, â€œwell of course they tried to keep him off the ballot, they tried to put him in jail and now you see this,â€ linking to a separate post about Bidenâ€™s comments to donors last week about it being â€œtime to put Trump in the bullseye.â€ LaCivita later deleted the post.

Weâ€™ll see if it lasts, but Trump himself says he is focused on shifting the message at the convention. â€œThe speech I was going to give on Thursday was going to be a humdinger,â€ he told the Washington Examiner yesterday. â€œHonestly, itâ€™s going to be a whole different speech now.â€ He added his primetime address will be â€œa chance to bring the country together. I was given that chance.â€

Worth Your Time

In addition to the societal and political turmoil, there was also a deep human cost to Saturdayâ€™s events: Two people were critically wounded and one, 50-year-old Corey Comperatore, was fatally shot. Danielle Paquette, Annie Gowen, and others spoke to Comperatoreâ€™s friends and family for a piece in the Washington Post. â€œThe shooting â€˜claimed the life of my brother,â€™ Dawn Comperatore Schafer wrote in a post on Facebook,â€ according to the Post. â€œThe hatred for one man took the life of the one man we loved the most.â€ Her younger brother had just turned 50 and had â€œso much life left to experience,â€ she wrote. â€œThis feels like a terrible nightmare but we know it is our painful reality.â€ Comperatore was the former chief of the Buffalo Township Volunteer Fire Company, and was an engineer by profession, according to a LinkedIn profile matching his name and photo. â€œAt the [Buffalo Township] fire station on Sunday, an American flag dangled at half-staff in honor of Comperatore. The chief, 59-year-old Kip Johnston, said he was struggling to process the fact that his friend of three decades was gone. How many afternoons had they shared in this office, listening to the fire scanner before charging out the door together? â€˜He was the first one running into a burning building,â€™ Johnston said.â€
